#: Chinese Proverbs: Learn Mandarin through Chinese Sayings
LEARN CHINESE by Alice Hunter January 3, 2019
So what are Chinese proverbs (谚语 yànyŭ in Chinese)?

data.x-pinyin: Qiānlǐ zhī xíng, shǐyú zú xià. Laozi.
data.en: Each 10,000 mile journey begins with just 1 step

#: PROVERB OF THE DAY - 07 MAR 2020

data.en: Dig the Well Before You Are Thirsty
#: English Translation: This proverb is a figurative way of saying: plan ahead, or be prepared.

data.zh-cn: 授人以鱼不如授人以渔
data.x-pinyin: Shòu rén yǐ yú bùrú shòu rén yǐ yú
data.en: Give a man a fish and you feed him for one day. Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime.
#: English Translation: This is a very well-known proverb, meaning that in the long-term it’s much more effective to teach someone how to do something for themselves than to simply do it for them.
In Chinese the saying can be literally translated to ‘Giving a man a fish is not equal to teaching a man to fish’.

data.x-pinyin: Chī yī qiàn, zhǎng yī zhì
data.en: By falling we learn to go safely.
#: English Translation: This proverb is all about learning from your experiences or mistakes. The Chinese word 堑 (qiàn) literally means moat or pit. So eat one pit/moat, grow one knowledge point.
There are several translations we can choose from in English. Here we’ve used: ‘By falling we learn to go safely’.
But more literal translations could be: ‘fall into the pit, a gain in your wit’ or ‘fall into the moat and you’ll be wiser next time’.

data.x-pinyin: bù pà màn, jiù pà tíng
data.en: Be not afraid of growing slowly, be afraid of standing still.
#: English Translation: This proverb means that the only thing we should be afraid of is stopping completely.
It reminds us to be patient and that some things take time, slow progress is still progress after all.

data.x-pinyin: Jī bùkě shī, shí bù zàilái
data.en: Opportunity knocks at the door only once.
#: Here 机(jī) means 机会 (jīhuì) opportunity, 不可失 (bùkě shī) referring to something that we can’t miss.
时不再来 – the time (时 shí) won’t come again another time.

data.en: Learn to walk before you run’.
#: The Chinese and English, when taken in literal terms, are quite different for this proverb.
In Chinese 一口 means one mouthful, 吃 (chī) eat, 不成 (bùchéng) impossible, and 胖子 (pàngzi) means a fat person (fatty).
Altogether, it’s impossible to become fat with just one mouthful.

data.x-pinyin: Shīfu lǐng jìnmén, xiūxíng zài gèrén
data.en: Teachers Open the Doors. You Enter by Yourself.
#: You enter by yourself: here 修行 (xiūxíng) literally means practise Buddhism or Daoism), but here refers to ‘the action of opening the door’. 在个人 (zài gèrén) means ‘is on the individual’.
In other words, the act itself is up to the individual.

data.zh-cn: 请教别人一次是5分钟的傻子，从不请教别人是一辈子的傻子
data.x-pinyin: Qǐngjiào biérén yīcì shì 5 fēnzhōng de shǎzi, cóng bù qǐngjiào biérén shì yībèizi de shǎzi
data.en: He who asks a question is a fool for five minutes; he who does not ask a question remains a fool forever.
#: In Chinese 请教 (qǐngjiào) means to ask someone for advice, 5 分钟的傻子 (fēnzhōng de shǎzi) means a 5 minute fool, whereas 一辈子的傻子 (yībèizi de shǎzi) means a fool for life.
